test_ralph_sig_chain._comment: Ralph is a test user I created by hand on my local server. I fetched his sigs and keys from the API, and then massaged them into our input format. This test is mainly to make sure that the generated chains we're using in other tests bear some relationship to reality.  - Jack

test_max_sig_chain._comment: This is Max Krohn's real live sigchain, as of 10 Aug 2017. The immediate reason for including it is the following interesting case: Max has revoked his very first link, which is both 1) a Twitter proof but also 2) implicitly delegates his eldest key. We should not treat this revocation as revoking the eldest key, and if we do, validating his chain will break.

test_simple_chain._comment: Test a simple chain, just one link.

test_error_unknown_key._comment: Check the case where a signing kid is simply missing from the list of available keys (as opposed to invalid for some other reason, like having been revoked).

test_error_unknown_reverse_sig_key._comment: As above, but for a reverse sig.

test_error_bad_signature._comment: Change some bytes from the valid signature, and confirm it gets rejected.

test_error_bad_reverse_signature._comment: Change some bytes from the valid reverse signature, and confirm it gets rejected.

test_error_mismatched_kid._comment: We need to use the server-provided KID to unbox a signature. We always need to check back after unboxing to make sure the internal KID matches the one we actually used. This test exercises that check. NOTE: I generated this chain by hacking some code into kbpgp to modify the payload right before it was signed.

test_error_mismatched_fingerprint._comment: We don't use fingerprints in unboxing, but nonetheless we want to make sure that if a chain link claims to have been signed by a given fingerprint, that does in fact correspond to the KID of the PGP key that signed it. NOTE: I generated this chain by hacking some code into kbpgp to modify the payload right before it was signed.

test_revokes._comment: The chain is unrevoked-length 17, but 4 sigs are revoked, so the apparent length should be 13. 5 sibkeys get delegated (plus the eldest), but 4 get revoked, for a final total of 2. Likewise 3 subkeys get delegated, but 2 get revoked, for a final total of 1.

test_error_revoked_key._comment: Try signing a link with a key that was previously revoked.

test_error_expired_key._comment: Try signing a link with a key that has expired. It should work since we're ignoring expirations.

test_error_empty_sigchain_eldest_key_is_._comment: NaCl keys don't have any internal userid info, so they can't stand alone as an eldest key without having signed some links.

test_jack_chain._comment: Just a sanity check with my own sigchain

test_error_missing_first_link._comment: We need to make sure the server can't drop links off the front. This would be a risk if we assumed that, for example, they belonged to a previous eldest key.

test_error_substitute_first_link._comment: Here the first link has been substituted for one signed by a different eldest key. We should notice the payload hash mismatch.

test_ralph_with_earlier_eldest_key._comment: Eldest keys can be reused, which means there can be subchains other than the latest one that correspond to the current eldest key. Those must be ignored. Previously, before we supported repeating eldest keys at all, we used to require that this was an error. Note that if the latest links don't correspond to the current eldest key, as we're testing here, that's an implicit reset, and we return no links.

test_melvin_with_expiring_pgp_key._comment: Right now this just exercises some of the code that recognizes the expiration time. Eventually we should add tests that make sure the etime is really enforced.

test_helen_chain._comment: A copy of t_helen's sigchain (also available as a permanent test user). Tests PGP keys with changing subkeys. She signed up with a PGP key, added a bitcoin address, and then changed that address, for a total of 3 sigchain links (but the first bitcoin link is revoked, so the final len is 2). In between each one she deleted the signing subkey that was used before and added a new one. So the only way to validate this sigchain is to do proper PGP key merging on all the bundles that the server returns. Note that the order of the key bundles given is intentionally rearranged, to make it less likely that the Go client will spuriously pass this test by only checking the last link against the last key.

test_pgp_subkey_after_revoke._comment: The eldest link is signed with a PGP key with an extra signing subkey, then a pgp_update link is used to update the key to a version where that subkey has been revoked. Then, another pgp_update link appears which tries to revert to the original version of the key, but is signed by the revoked subkey.

test_pgp_bad_full_hash._comment: The eldest link is signed with a PGP key and includes a full_hash which doesn't match the key

test_pnelsen_sigchain._comment: pnelsen was one of several users affected by the 15 Sep 2015 white-space stripping bug on the server

test_akalin_sigchain._comment: Fred has some unverifiable links in his chain from old bugs of ours. These need to be special cased.

test_repeat_eldest._comment: We now define 'eldest' links to imply a sigchain reset. This is a basic test case with two links, both of type eldest, delegating the same eldest key. Old clients would've parsed this as a 2-link chain (where the second link was a no-op), but conforming clients should respect the reset adn return a 1-link chain.

test_hardcoded_reset._comment: Several users (6) managed to do a sigchain reset and reuse their eldest key without an 'eldest' link, before we prohibited that on the server. This test uses the chain of one of those users, as a canary to make sure they're covered.

test_v1_v2_stubbed_mix._comment: A chain some V1, some V2 links, and some are stubbed

test_v2_stubbed._comment: A chain with all V2 links, and some are stubbed

test_v2_simple._comment: A chain with all V2 links, but none are stubbed

test_bad_v2_delegate_stubbed._comment: A chain that has a key delegate stubbed (a no-no)

test_bad_v2_first_stubbed._comment: A chain that has an eldest link stubbed (a no-no)

test_bad_v2_hash_mismatch._comment: A chain that has a link=2 wrong hash to body

test_bad_v2_prev_mismatch._comment: A chain that has a link=2 wrong prev

test_bad_v2_seqno_mismatch._comment: A chain that has a link=2 wrong seqno

test_bad_v2_type_mismatch._comment: A chain that has a link=2 type subkey v sibkey mismatch

test_v2_with_revokes._comment: A chain with all V2 links, and some revokes, 1 stubbed link

test_bad_v2_stubbed_revoke_sig._comment: A chain with all V2 links, with an errant stubbed revoke sig

test_bad_v2_stubbed_revoke_sigs._comment: A chain with all V2 links, with an errant stubbed revoke sig

test_bad_v2_revoke_type_mismatch._comment: A chain with all V2 links, with an errant stubbed revoke sig

test_bad_v2_wrong_payload_hash._comment: A chain with a payload_hash that doesn't match the has of the outer

00dani._comment: 00dani's chain got broken after pgp key update with invalid usage flags.

goozbach._comment: goozbach's chain got broken after revoking and adding pgp key, wrong bundle was used to verify reverse_sig.

reset_2x._comment: a sigchain that was reset 2x and has 3 eldest links therefore

test_per_user_key._comment: Test a simple per user key link.

test_bad_per_user_key_reverse_sig._comment: a sigchain per user key addition with an corrupted reverse sig

test_v2_unsupported_with_ignore._comment: a V2 signature with an unsupported link that it's OK to ignore

test_v2_unsupported_with_ignore_stubbed._comment: a V2 signature with an unsupported, stubbed link that it's OK to ignore

test_v2_unsupported_no_ignore._comment: a V2 signature with an unsupported link that it's not OK to ignore

test_v2_unsupported_no_ignore_stubbed._comment: a V2 signature with an unsupported, stubbed link that it's not OK to ignore
